-Y82HIxWY8JXA7h8vutEoA.text: Dishes are absolutely delicious, high quality Italian cusine! Staff recomended us some lovely dishes, and that was the right choice, we enjoyed so much. They were kind and atentive. You must have a reservation, If you don't - prepare yourself for waiting.

TxyM5k6M4VUgq7XXavlGkg.text: Bocca Di Lupo is an Italian restaurant that has dishes covering different regions in Italy. We tried:- Seabream carpaccio with orange & rosemary - to get the full flavour of this dish you will need to sqeeze some orange juice, otherwise I thought it lacked flavour.- Grilled mussels with chilli oils - a simple dish that was nice, but it would not be a stand out dish for me at Bocca Di Lupo.- Bagna fredda (chilled anchovy & garlic cream with fennel, potatoes, bread and mammole artichoke) - an interesting dish where you dip the vegetables and bread in a soup looking sauce. The dipping was full of flavour which made it suited to go with the bread and vegetable which was on the bland side.- The Caponata (aubergines, celery and tomato in agrodolce) come in the option to be served cold or warm. I prefer it warm. Love that the vegetable cooked until it is soft and it compliment the meat dishes.- I found the texture of the risotto too hard. Although a good risotto is al dente but I thought it was too much with a crunchy side. Alternatively the pasta did not disappoint us.Bocca Di Lupo's roast/grilled dishes on the menu was the highlight of my evening.- Whole slow grilled leg of milk fed lamb with garlic, wine and honey. This dish cost £55 which is for two person to share. The meat was tender with a sweet honey taste.- Roast suckling pig with chestnuts, white wine & bay leaves for £26 would be my second favourite dish of the evening. Crispy skin with succelant meat under it.- Agnell cacio e uiva (lamb braised with white wine sauce thickened with egg yolks and pecorino) I thought by look was not a pretty dish on the plate.We managed to finish our meal with dessert, but unfortunately some of the dessert were already sold out although it was not even 9 o'clock.- The Bonet (chocolate, coffee, amaretti, caramel & rum pudding) was very sweet and is for those with a very sweet tooth. For me one or two spoonfuls is enough to satisfy my sweet buds.- The Baba with baked rhubarb and cream I thought was like bread soaked in water. The portion size of this can be share. Compared to the bonet this was not sweet and more on refresh side. But it was my least favourite dessert of the evening as soggy bread really does not take my fancy.I did enjoyed the food at Bocca Di Lupo but I was disappointed by the service. Our waitress obviously was trying to get us to finish so they could turn the table. Me and few of us arrived 20 minutes early than our booking and we were shown to our table. However, even before our booking time we were already push to order and asked when the rest of our guests were arriving.I was already aware that we only had the table for 2 hours and 15 minutes. So when we were offered the dessert menu and needed to give the table back on time, we tried many time to politely get attention of a staff to take our order. Finally when our waitress wanted to take our dessert, she comes over and decided to take the menus off us, giving us the impression that we had no time for dessert.I know they are busy and want to turn as many tables throughout the night. But I think our waitress could had done it in a much more polite way. Other restaurant has been able to do it in a much better way. I wouldn't recommend this place if you don't want to feel push with your dining.

jh8xduMQuV0t-v2wo6W5Ig.text: Where do I even begin - The food here is overpriced for the portions you get. Staff is really rude and will treat you like trash if you don't appear to be old or wealthy enough. Service is absolutely HORRIBLE - they turned away two friends that came along with us (even though we had a table booked) because they had a toddler with them and apparently this place despises kids. Also, we were there for a friend's birthday, and wanted to cut a birthday cake while we were there. Staff quoted us a figure of 10 pounds PER HEAD (i.e. 10x10=GBP100 TO LET US USE THEIR CUTLERY AND SING A BIRTHDAY SONG IN THEIR PREMISES). When we asked what other options we have instead of paying this exorbitant fee, the witty waitress told us to go to a garden in Soho and cut the cake there (like a bunch of hobos). Anyways, food was mediocre and SOME dishes were okay. However, just don't bloody come here... until they do something about their shitty service.

hY6NP8-vMSctl7pQmoI9dw.text: Every dishes are full of surprises! Small sizes are good for shares, very nice place to go for a pre-theatre dinner!

NEVLpcVW06XM_hjUVHp_xg.text: Was able to find a table for a large group fast The waiter who took the order was rude , which gave a negative vibe to the placeWe ordered the fried sages , buratta cheese , bruschetta as appetisers (all good except the fried sages)The tagliatelle mushroom was ok , and the sea bass was very good .

HUO1U5PyjaYkAzvIQwtVzg.text: Some of the best, authentic Italian food I've ever eaten.   Had the opportunity to sit at the bar and enjoy this meal all while watching Noah, a young chef on staff cook.  He was awesome.  The dishes were excellent and menu was presented in an Italian tapas style so you get to sample many different preparations and dishes. Reasonable prices as well.

stW2gDLrwj91lwcvpkB32w.text: Accommodated me at the bar with no reservation. One of those bars that's too high to eat off of but fine. Sat right in front of the head chef which was cool to watch.  All dishes had a small and large side which I appreciated as a solo diner. I got to try more things than usual so great for family style, if you are into that sort of thing. Best dish was the starter of tuna confit mixed with arugala tomatoes fava beans and onion. Tuna had so much flavor and fatty tasting goodness. Think this was a special for the day though. Next had the linguine with tomato sauce with squid and added clams. Good but nothing mind blowing. Then tried a fennel sausage over bed of tasted onions and finished with an espresso gelato. Gelato had a very good espresso flavor. Food was great would go back.

dVlItfzME6Mht5HPV41EAg.text: One of my faves when I'm in London. They are very easy to accommodate you without a reservation. Although highly recommended to do so. I recommend almost everything in the menu... And yes I do eat a lot!.

E4QDZ98R_q0KKQwApzkXOA.text: The food was good, but if you are looking for those favorite basics, like Spaghetti and Meatballs, Lasagna, Bruschetta, or Garlic Bread, you won't find that here.

W9jLnTKzq-ua35MvvjRCYw.text: This is my favorite restaurant in the whole world and it is what I miss the most about my brief 6 months in London. Everything is fresh, in season and absolutely delicious! I highly recommend the sweet breads, the orecchiette, king scallops, sage leaves with anchovy.. It is a little difficult to get a reservation. I suggest reserving for two people via open table and asking to be seated at the counter by the by window side. It is pricy but they have a pre theater menu is that's less expensive.

jXf-Bur9q-fSIHFFjeMvhQ.text: After reading a number of rave reviews for this place, and having a lot of people highly recommend it, it was a big disappointment. We ordered a variety of small dishes for the four of us. The black risotto and the veal saltimbocca were great dishes with a lot of flavour and textures, but the remainder failed to impress. The tagliatelle ragu - pasta was definitely overcooked. The lamb chops were over-fried with rather limited flavour. The sides were underwhelming as well. The mozzarella was as expected. Overall there was nothing that we had that would make me say - wow I want to come back!Went to gelupo next door for dessert which never disappoints.

S6j1Rpzqvi-tl5uRy5_SZg.text: Probably my favorite Italian restaurant in London. Have eaten here at least 4 times and it has always been great. Service is really good.You can have small dishes which is a great idea because you can try more of their specialities. If you seat at the bar, that is by the kitchen, you can enjoy the chefs cooking for you.  I had the fried artichoke, which is delicious and also so petty. The carpaccioThe incredible burratta and tomato saladAnd the lobster risotto.Dessert menu is also fabulous, but last time I had eaten too much and decided to slip it. Highly recommend restaurant

wCq0LeO4AI70m6lIDVqxhg.text: I adore the taste of Ricotta Ravioli with broad bean pure and peppercorn. I think it's my favourite meal on earth from now on. I haven't ate a dish so cooked to perfection lately. The combination of flavours is fantastic and I wouldn't mind eating it every day for lunch. They have an outstanding selection of other pasta meals and this restaurant goes to my top 5 of Italians in London. The portions, like in decent Italian restaurants are huge and enough to share. Who's coming back with me to eat Spaghetti?

Hrtu6Z4fW4NMFVzgA-a6zQ.text: The best Italian food I've had in London.There. I've said it. No, really. Can I give six stars? At least five and a half? Please?I need to get all of this down now before (God forbid) I start forgetting things, and whilst still under the influence of a warm afterglow from having had truly spectacular food.And the small/large plate distinction. Fanbloodytastic. In the end, 7 smaller dishes came to the same price as 3 large ones. And my God I was glad for the opportunity to try more of this amazing food.My only disappointment, honestly, was that the best (main) dish of the day - the fried sage leaf with anchovies - was the first thing I tried. I think I made a face, contorted with such bliss, that must have made me look (even more of) a loony (than usual). Salty, crunchy, wonderfully balanced.Milky, perfectly-fried balls of mozzarella were delightful. I've not seen this level of skill much outside of Japan, to be perfectly honest - and the ingredients were just of the best possible quality.A singular pasta dish - why, oh why, was there only one pasta dish - was exquisite - the orechiette as beloved by so many other Yelpers - and I'm running out of superlatives here. Perfect pasta. I soaked up the rest of the wonderfully spicy and yet complex pasta sauce with a little of the remaining bread with completely undisguised glee.A risotto was perhaps the only slight let-down. But then I've never really been a fan of risotto so I must on this occasion defer judgement - the waitress suggested that today's rendition was slightly too cheesy and slightly too creamy - completely without prompting - and whilst I admire the honesty, that's a level of criticism that even I find too harsh.Drinks.I only had one - an Aperol Spritz. It was, by some distance, the best example of the drink I've ever had - almost certainly due to the use of anything other than bargain-basement Prosecco. Beautiful and so refreshing on what was otherwise a glorious May weekend.Dessert of profiteroles was as close to perfection as anything I've ever had the pleasure of eating. The pastry very much played second fiddle to more than generous portions of tiramisu, gianduja and ricotta and cherry ice cream, the latter of which might just have been perfect. I'm only really ashamed to admit that I only licked about half of the plate clean.Service was cheeky, and all the better for it - always attentive, patient and unlike in some establishments of this calibre, not at all condescending. Incredible service in an Italian restaurant? Who'da thunk it?And all this for just over £30 per head with drinks and service. I'm already desperate to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom. Mozzarella balls and sage leaves stuffed with anchovies
Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom. Profiteroles with gianduja, tiramisu and ricotta and cherry ice cream filling.

1bSFzh8W3EWoP9Biw-J_EA.text: Delicious, original and well cooked cuisine. Daisy took great care of us sitting at the counter. Had a bunch of small plates-prawns were scrumptious, caponata delicious and chunky,chick peas one if my faves. Pasta with artichokes perfectly cooked. Have the house wine and end with homemade desserts. Super service with great passion and gusto.Highly recommend

FFNKQDbEnWDm0Wd_DBuVMw.text: We enjoyed a wonderful dinner here last night. Everything from the warm greeting on our arrival to the lively dining room was appealing. We started with i suppli Romani which were better than any suppli we had in Rome. Their watermelon salad with thin slices of the sweet fruit topped with red onion, cracked black pepper and a drizzle of olive oil was a fantastic surprise. The meatball with peas and a side of spinach topped off the meal along with a fantastic bottle of Nebbiolo. I would highly recommend Bocca do Lupo to anyone craving Italian food in London!

vjLHbjItYdAQcKPru2KeRA.text: Bocca Di Lupo was somewhere I'd always been interested in trying so was delighted when my friend suggested it. We got a table at 5.15pm on Sunday having booked I believe that morning. Although you have a 2 hour slot we were able to stay until almost 8pm. They ask at the beginning if you have theatre reservations so presumably speed things up if they know you need to leave promptly.The drinks menu is impressive. There's a wide selection of pre-dinner drinks including vermouth and some excellent cocktails including a lovely amaro sour my friend liked so much she continued drinking through the dinner. There's an equally extensive wine menu and after dinner drinks menu, including many dessert wines and grappa. I really like the serious focus on presenting a wide range of Italian drinks. They have a sommelier and some of the servers seem to abdicate all responsibility for understanding what is they offer as a result - so if you want good advice I'd say go for the sommelier no matter how over-egged that seems for one glass wine. Price points I thought were very good, especially for the wine.Food-wise it's mixed. The croquettes were a stand-out, the fried bufala bocconcini had too much liquid in it and was tasteless. Aubergine busiate tasted weirdly of (my favourite) pumpkin ravioli with sage and butter - maybe it was the involvement of the latter two ingredients but odd overall, it felt like something sweeter (albeit delicious) had inappropriately interloped. Fennel sausage was tasty but perhaps expensive at £7 for what is essentially one medium sized sausage. Saltimbocca was not what we expected but had a distinctive marsala flavour and was worth a try. Tortellini was not good - both dry and hard, frankly an insult to Bologna. Bread and oils were outstanding.Atmosphere it's noisy (so glad I had cancelled, in the past, a dinner here with my hearing-impaired father) and a little cramped, although my initial anxiety at 3 kids arriving at the table next to us was totally unfounded as they were impressively well-behaved and I overheard one kid ordering pasta with tomato sauce (not on menu) to which server didn't blink an eye (it's interesting other reviewers have had negative experiences with children. I certainly didn't witness this - although I have to say I think this is a weird place to bring children as it's quite fancy and expensive but if you have money to burn then go for it). I admired the giant and elegant light fixture at the back of the dining room and overall felt positive about the vibe. Service wasn't 100% as we were left a little long at points but overall was attentive and extremely friendly and helpful.It's not perfect but drinks and service are a solid 4 and I'd say if you come here for a few drinks and small plates at the bar, rather than a major meal, you'll enjoy.

Ou1BurOSwcAmJMa968WIJA.text: In terms of food, I give this place 4 stars. The goat ragu pasta was incredible as was the octopus stew, and the langoustine and prawn risotto. The fried courgette flower with mozzarella and anchovies was nice but a bit too oily. So why the 3 stars? I was looking for a good rose wine recommendation as it was lunch time when I went. The server was absolutely clueless and hopeless in recommending anything. From a restaurant which is fully booked out 2 months in advance for Fri and Sat evenings, I would expect a sommelier on staff and if not, at least knowledgable waiting staff. When I asked her if I could try a rose, her response was no. I asked her if she could recommend something, and her response was "I don't know". I expect better from a place with such hype.

photos.caption: Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom

C4gXgccHEMSsZveRUjnFsg.text: Good food:We ordered the:Chicken scallopini  - great Watermelon, onion and oregano salad - good Courgette flower stuffed with mozzarella & anchovy - amazing (I usually don't like anchovy but was delicious)Squid and lemon slices - ok Squid with linguini- skip A sea bream cooked in a salt shell - okIt's really a 3.5 Star rating that may go to 4 if I go back and have a knock out pasta dish!

ZgTvyzglVzNPt-SJWzqJ8w.text: First night in London and here I am. First off my thanks to front of house staff they helped me get a spot at the bar.  This place is jumping. I ordered about the menu and my two top plates were the stuffed olives and the rigatoni with tomatoes and calf milk intestines. Both are go to dishes. The arranchini was bland and the salad was over dressed.Diffidently a repeat.

Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom

03lMOKGH7h0r-zw7HunZ4w.text: One of the best teas taut are in London Hands down!  My good friend Sasha Allen 1st visited this place 10 yrs ago and she makes and effort to have all the seafood dishes every time she comes!  Everything was tasty!

FLKYGMz-t3L7J-4-cEbCYQ.text: We are convinced that this is likely the best Italian food in London.  We've been coming here for 7 years and have loved everything we've tried; the staff has been consistently courteous and well-informed, too.  On our last visit, we had their aubergine melanzane (as well as a delicious ravioli and spaghetti), which was so memorable I would be very happy to make the trip back to London from San Francisco for another bite.  Highly recommended but *do* book a reservation in advance as they fill up quickly for both lunch and dinner, every day of the week.  Try to save room to try to the focaccia that comes with the meal, and for gelato across the street at Gelupo.

gtx-zbH7E7RvCuxWowwjkQ.text: I absolutely love this place. Everything about this restaurant is perfect. The service, the food, the wine selection, and the atmosphere was just lovely. I had a good experience here.It seems to be crowded and occupied during dinner time, best make prior reservations. I like the interior of this restaurant, as you enter there's an open kitchen with a long bar table that heads towards the back where there are more tables. If you don't mind seated side by side, the bar table is actually fine for two!The food is amazing. We ordered a bunch of starters to share and mains to share (unfortunately I can't remember them all). The Ravioli pumpkin is a must try! Almost feels as though the filling is melting in my mouth! The Tagliatelle with wild Venison should also be in your list of things to order (but I suspect this is seasonal). If you order the Fossil Fish, be careful of the bones. It's very nicely cooked, the meat is soft and juicy. We decided to try "Grandpa's Balls" out of curiosity, I don't remember it being particularly mind blowing but it was a nice sweet dessert to end the meal.The prices are slightly on the higher side but given its quality I would say it's worth the bill. Highly recommend .

photos.caption: Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom. Ravioli Pumpkin
Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom. Fossil fish - sea bream charred in a crust of flour & salt
Photo of Bocca Di Lupo - London, United Kingdom. Le palle del nonno - "Grandpa's balls"

-kq-NnYLDr4_e9G2tt5uVw.text: Outstanding!  Food and service.  All homemade food and try to sit at bar near open kitchen and watch the magic.  Some of the best Italian I've had.

pIroBE79uIfZdkZYv_2ebg.text: What a magical place! First, you gotta get yourself a reservation. You can't walk in here unless you plan on waiting for awhile and they don't want you to leave or you will have your wait time start over, nor is there really a bar to wait at as it's being occupied by diners that also have a reservation. So first rule, get a reservation. A group of us were lucky to snag a reservation on a Friday night at the bar and it was perfect. We had an amazing waitress that expertly portioned out the meal selections for us. She was friendly and knew so much about food and drink. You could sense her passion for the menu items and Italian culture. It was refreshing to be around someone so enchanted by the food and drink the place was putting out. The food was soooooooooo good. Wow. Dish-after-dish we were impressed. You can't go wrong with homemade pastas. Always go with the ravioli! They're pockets of love! The suckling pig and polenta was another highlight. We got a bunch of items to split and everyone left full and a smile on their face. Love it! Wish I was a local to get back here more frequently. Very fun place to dine and kick off a night on the town.

BDJCDKgUpQ2evARLD4fvgA.text: Second time here was as great as the first time. To make things even better the server remembered me from last year. Food is fabulous here everything I have tried I loved. The portions are good to share if you want to try several things.Reservations are a must, I booked the dinner reservation about one and a half months in advance and the only time I could get was 10:15PM.

gz7UNOI_SDzm6CVUcodBGA.text: Don't waste your money here.Nothing related to Italian food. Too much gourmet but not good food.They changed the menu so the photos are old and are totally different now.We didn't touch the food and they charged $90 even not attending our expectations.Customers are in the bottom line here!

vF8PdHQB0gTvKeyTJe9j-Q.text: We walked in the restaurant without reservation and we were told the wait time was 45 minutes. We decided to wait, and it's so weird that they asked us to wait inside standing next to the bar but not at the bar. We were told the bar area required reservations. It's kind of weird, but it's good that we got seated at the bar pretty soon. What I like about this place is that you can order small plates and try more dishes. They also have different kinds of pasta and wine selection. The wine they recommended was good. We tried - gnudi with lamb ragú - the lamb and sauce are pretty good. It's my first time to try gnudi, so I'm not a big fan. - rigatoni con la pajata - it is the best among all. The pasta is cooked perfectly. - grilled giant tiger prawns - it doesn't taste as good as I expected. - grilled quail - the meat is pretty tender - tortellini - good The service here is a bit slow though even though they said in the beginning that we have a dining time limit of 1.5 hours.

vAjKpZB35qgHPce4aJt7Kg.text: When in London, you MUST visit this restaurant---and make sure to get a reservation!  You WILL NOT regret it!I visited Bocca di Lupo on a recent business trip to London.  This restaurant was recommended to me by my Father-in-Law and I stayed up until the wee hours of the morning to make a reservation for the bar.  The bar is a ringside seat to the open kitchen where you can watch the magicians of Italian food at work.  Now, for those of your from the United States, understand that the portions are small.  The pricing scheme here is pretty reasonable and it is encouraged that your order 3 or 4 plates of food.  It's a terrific concept that I wish would be more prevalent in the United States.  I started off with a special for the evening, sea bream Carpaccio with orange.  Until dining here, I had never eaten sea bream---holy smokes was I missing out!  First, since I was seated at the bar, I watched the Chef delicately filet the sea bream and slice the thinnest pieces of fresh fish and then season it with orange and some amazing olive oil.  The fish was clean and fresh tasting.  It was firm yet melted in my mouth and it didn't have the overly "fishy" taste that one can find with other fish.  The layers of flavor with the sea bream paired with the orange and the olive oil is indescribable.  This plate was gone before I knew it, and I wanted more!  It looks as though Bocca di Lupo has added this dish to their menu, so make sure to order and it--you will be glad you did.  For those who may be wondering...yes, the fish is raw.  My second dish was tagliatelle with bolognese ragu.  Wow!  Since the pasta is fresh, it is incredibly tender and cooked to perfection.  The sauce was so good, I am pretty sure it would make a shoe taste pretty darn good.  As stated earlier, the plates are small, and I wish I had more of this pasta!  My next dish was risotto with porcini mushrooms.  I don't normally get excited over risotto, but this was akin to eating a cloud...with mushrooms!  The porcinis were cut perfectly and incorporated into the risotto perfectly.  To finish off my carb heavy dinner, I enjoyed a plate of gnocchi with sausage and spicy tomato sauce.  The little pillows made of potato dough and covered with a spicy arrabiata sauce were amazing!  I am normally not a big fan of gnocchi as some chefs can make them a bit too dense, but this was like eating little baby clouds.  The gnocchi were light and airy, the sauce was not too spicy but perfectly balanced.  The sausage---WOW!  It was packed full of flavor!  The entire dish worked so well together I had to force myself to stop eating it since I was full from the other courses.  I left Bocca di Lupo so stuffed, I looked forward to walking around London to stave off the inevitable food coma which I knew was coming my way.  This was one of the best meals I have ever had, and I totally look forward to returning back here the next time I am in London.  Make sure you do the same!

sNAzSApAfHtJf81qMNt0Ug.text: We came here mid week on a warm summer evening when soho was packed so we were impressed to be able to be seated within 30 mins for a table of 4. The restaurant is small inside but didn't feel cramped and the staff were really friendly and helpful, especially in recommending dishes for one of our friends who cannot eat gluten. We shared a bunch of dishes including:Gnudi with lamb ragu - best dish we had! Ricotta filled dumplings served with really good ragu. Glad we got the large size of this one!Galletto in spring panzanella - a whole baby chicken with a type of pee purée (better than anything you've had a fish and chip shop!) - really well cooked with great flavours, generous portion.Langoustine and prawn risotto - another good dish.Chicken scallopine - really flavourful but it is literally chicken scallops so make sure you order a side too.

_4eb-TEXeQMt3Dqc7yTkVg.text: Had read so many good reviews however it didn't live up to expectations I think the starters were slightly overpriced although good. Have to say, one fried artichoke for 5£, bit steep. Other starters included the fried squid which was good although nothing different than a regular calamari. The soft shell crab dish was low on the crabs but a fair few shrimps. Had a couple of the arancini but for the price , again over priced.The mains included the ragu dish which was Ecco, my favorite of the group. Two squid ink risottos which to be honest was a bit bland. The veal chop for two, was my least favorite - I'm not a fan of pink veal so at least the option for how we wanted it cooked would have been nice. In addition to it being pink, it was cold and lacking salt. The meat wasn't cutting properly off the bone, lots of meat was left on it.The table in the back wasn't ideal - people constantly went back and forth through the curtain which was distracting due to light and chair bumping.Overall the group enjoyed the restaurant, but I wouldn't come back anytime soon as there are better places for food and additionally for value.Service was decent, no complaints there.

STGw8OnxBizOzy4H74XkLA.text: I can't understand the high rating for this place and the crowds waiting to dine here. I came here for dinner and my experience was terrible. First, the portions were ridiculously small. I paid about £10 for 2 golf ball size appetizers. The large size order of my pasta was small as well. It was only about 225gm. Secondly, the 10gm white truffle I paid £45 at a sister location next door tasted dry and flavorless. It smelled good but I didn't expect it to taste so bland. Lastly, the agnolotti del plin I had my truffles put on was so salty that I had to force myself to finish it knowing how much I paid for the white truffles.  Overall I felt cheated leaving this place. Sure I'm a tourist visiting London and I may not be back for some time. No need for mgmt to worry too much about people like me. I'm still curious who finds this place so amazing to warrant such a high rating.

eamu5vVB-K9Ri23PTfJWrw.text: Came here for an early New Year's Eve dinner with a friend. It was very busy inside and the atmosphere was lovely, especially for such a small restaurant. We ordered quite a few small plates to share, and while I found everything tasty, the one distinctive memory I walked away with was for the truffled radish, celeriac, and pomegranate salad. Wow! This salad is what dreams are made of! Of all things to rave about at a popular place like this, I will acknowledge that salad isn't usually it. But all I can say is, if there was one menu item to bring me back to this place, it would be this one. Amazing!

YTpqKlk3PRzoZ1Lj6YYrFw.text: It was Friday date night and was able to get a reservation at Bocca di Lupo which has been on our list for awhile. Food: Since its a tapas style menu, we ordered the following.  Please note you can order a small or large portion of each on their menu:Crescentine with Parma Ham (small order) - Delicious.  The bread they serve it with was to die for.  The only drawback is that they only give you two pieces when you could eat ten.  The Parma ham portion is generous and the squacquerone cheese is a nice accompaniment.Tortellini (small order) - This is the best tortellini I've tasted so far.  It's made with veal, pork, radicchio and nutmeg.  I regretted not ordering the large portion after we received it because I could've eaten 50 pieces.Braised Ox Cheek with Chocolate and Spices  (small order) - Yum!  Wasn't sure what to expect with the chocolate, but it was very subtle and complimented the dish overall very nicely.  The meat was very tender and full of flavor.Grilled Langoustines and Mussels in a Chilli Garlic Sauce (small order) - The dish was good and had a kick with the chili.  Sucking Pig (can only order large) - The pork exceeded our expectations.  It was perfectly cooked and the sauce was light and complimented it very well.Broccoli and Cimi de Rape with Garlic and Chilli (small order) - This was our least favorite of the dishes.  The vegetables were overcooked and very mushy.  For Dessert - We ordered the Bombe Calde which are their donuts.  Thank god there were only three because they were so delicious I could've eaten ten.Drinks: We ordered two bellinis and one 500ml of the Primitivo red wine.Price: 137.48 GBP for two people.  It's expensive for what you receive overall.Ambiance: The restaurant was very busy and had a good vibe.  We sat at the bar to be up front with the chefs which we always like to do.Service: The service was very good.  Our server was friendly, helpful and attentive.Would I go back?  Definitely!  Even if I just ordered a large order of the tortellinis myself.

K5oeYFROJu_yNaX8BtNe6Q.text: How do you say 'yum' in Italian? Awesome meal again. Grilled squid and prawns to start. Then partridge off the truffle menu with amazing polenta, romanesco with spinach and orecchiette with red onion and tomato. Everything was delicious. Service was friendly and low key. It all went smoothly despite a few small mishaps. Can't wait to come back!

MenOeAtpC4GiAEbQ63B5WA.text: After recently visiting London, we decided to head out in search of some good eats and came across this trendy little place tucked away down a side street.As soon as we arrived we were immediately made to feel welcomed and valued guests, we had made reservations an although the table wasnt free instantly (in fact a 20 min wait) being plied with free drinks is certainly my kind of customer service!As we were waiting we manager came over and had a chat with us several times to update us on the wat and asking us if we wanted more drinks, which i thought was a nice touch. This waiting period also gave us the opportunity to peek at what delights were in store.We ordered a whole bunch of dishes, this is because you can order small plates and treat it kinda like an Italian tapas, which is brilliant as there are so many things that look delicious.We settled for prosciutto cheese and bread starter, along with a wild boar and olive selection. All were very good although curing boar intensifies the flavour into really quite an overpowering taste. Ii personally didnt think much of the pickled porcinni though.This was followed by a wild boar ragu and fresh pasta (not our first choice because the one we wanted had sold out!) It was sooooo good though an i wasnt even slightly disappointed at my second choice.We also ordered a rabbit leg in the most divine tomato sauce, it had so much depth of flavour i mopped it up with the rosemary foccacia. For dessert we had espresso gratini and hazelnut gelato with a sweet alcohol shot to pour over according to taste; i order my coffee with dessert, Bicerni i think it was called and oh my god, the best tasting thing ever when eating with a spoon complimented with the hazelnut gelato! This may seem weird but the Bicerni is quiye a thick blend of coffee and hot chocolate that tastes like liquid heaven!Genuinely i think the best meal iv ever had as a whole, impeccable service, delicious food and a great relaxed atmosphere (even for a Northerner 'abroad')

7H_5spAEHHzipkTmfpAdnQ.text: Slightly mystified by the hype of this place. 1. The food - most importantly, of course. Now, I'm speaking as a veggie, so I didn't get to try the meat/fish - perhaps this is where the restaurant shines. But even then, I'm always unimpressed by restaurants who can't manage veggie options well, particularly Italian restaurants. Now, that's not to say food was bad. The pasta was sublime, if a bit of a small portion for a large portion, if you get my drift. But the tapas-style starters? Very hit and miss - with more towards the slightly bland miss than the extra-tasty hit. 2. Ambience - cluttered, over-stuffed, loud. 3. Staff - noticeably honed in on high value customers to the detriment of others. The utterly smart architecty looking couple next to us got lavish attention, me and my not-so-scruffy dining partner? Fairly surly and inattentive behaviour. It couldn't have been more blatant - either they're underpaid and going after tips, or they're being instructed by management to lavish attention on people they think they can talk up on the wine list. Whichever it is, it's not being done subtly enough to not piss off other diners. In the end, then, as I said at the top, this is slightly mystifying. It's a competent and occasionally brilliant Italian. But it's let down in several key areas and I won't be rushing to eat there again. If I want high ticket Italian food in central London, there's lots of other, better choices (Locatelli. Mmmmm...).

I6emJ5-Lk9lyWeDyep6IzA.text: Bocca di Lupo does great Italian dishes that you can either enjoy tapas style or having starters and main courses. Seating in the restaurant is either at tables or on a bar that faces the kitchen and bar areas. I would recommend sitting at the bar as, although the seats were perhaps a little low the table area looked like it had a much less enjoyable ambience.Sitting at the bar you get to see all the dishes being made and sent out. This is a mixed blessing as now I have to go at least another 2 times to try all the dishes that looked so great. I do feel sometimes that having full view of the kitchen can destroy the magic a little bit but it also added to the entertainment. The head chef wasn't working so the second chef led the kitchen and called his cooks darling when giving orders.We initially ordered slightly too much food and one of the waiting staff very helpfully suggested that we might like to change some of our upcoming dishes, which we did. In fact the wait staff were very helpful, if sometimes a little disorganised., which we found quite charming.In fact there was only one reason I haven't given this place 5 stars - Braised Escarole. That they even have this dish on the menu deserves to lose it a star, never mind that they offer it as a main. This vegetable was impossible to cut with the cutlery provided and whilst it initially tasted good in the mouth it left quite an unpleasant bitter after-taste that outlived the sweet accompaniments on the dish. I can only hope that it wasn't cooked properly and that it's not actually meant to be as disappointing as it was.A real highlight dish is the seafood linguine. It was by far the best I've had and tasted so richly of the sea. The pasta was perfectly cooked in a way I could never replicate.

zVtFJiavV_YwUKYv9iJuLg.text: 3.5 stars.  we came in a large group and tried a bunch of stuff.  they start you off w/ foccacia, bread, and olives which were good.i tried the fried balls w/ squid ink and the one w/ saffron and bone marrow.  i honestly couldn't taste the squid ink or the saffron/bone marrow in either of them and only really tasted rice.for my entree, i got the small order of john dory, which was big enough for me.  i also tried the oriechitte w/ broccoli raab, which was tasty.  i also liked the caponata w/ anchovies, roasted pumpkin, and broccoli raab.we didn't have time for dessert but went across the way to gelupo.  all in all, a pretty good meal.

wbjoVSrO59_v18Vi1k5Faw.text: I've only been here once as well, and it was pre-theatre.  Nevertheless, Bocca Di Lupo did everything perfectly.  No overstatement: it was quite possibly the best meal i've had in 5 years in London. Everything was excellent: the service, the food, the menu, the decor, the ambiance, even the price.I didn't have much time to savour the experience, what with the limited time between work and the show, and its a testament to the waiters that i somehow managed a great meal including starters and coffee at a pace that never seemed rush.Me and my friend sat at the bar, and watched our food being prepared.  Unlike so many other open kitchens, this was somehow pleasant.  It worked brilliantly for friends, though for some dates it would perhaps be advised to get a table at the back.  The wine was on-par with the food: delightful.  The sausages and the risotto are beyond compare.  Everything is well presented, and without pretensions.  Not ostentatious, but well done and special.Reservations are more or less essential.

4GqvvwvEI5Uac51DT7sdgg.text: Below average food, slow and hurried service and wines by the glass that are hardly drinkable. It is truly surprising that this place is so popular. There are way too many great restaurants in London to bother with such low quality place.

DKlnn30tLgaKinsaDNo-9A.text: Went to Bocca di Lupo with a friend last Feb, and i wondered how i've missed this decent italian place in Soho for the past 3 years ! LocationSoho, so it's perfect ! Food & WineWine is beautiful, no complaint. Most servings are not huge and that's a good thing. There are enough interesting items on the menu for one to order several dishes to sample. A little pricey but slightly above average quality (personally, I'd prefer that to cheap~ave prices but forgettable food). Dessert, we wanted tiramisu, which is only available in large portion. We asked the chef and he kindly let us ordered half of the large portion (half is still large !). The tiramisu is lovely, and I am guessing the secret ingredient is dates ?? ......... My friend ate and drank more than her usual portion that evening, so that's a good attestation. ServiceI had a table booked but we arrived 10mins late, and our table was given to someone else (granted they rang me earlier but i wasn't able to pick up the call). no problem as they offered us seats at the counter, which we accepted. It turned out to be a fantastic night, regardless, as the generous aussie guys sitting next to us at the counter shared their red wine, and we discussed philosophically what "short term, long term" is :D Will definitely return, and recommend to a friend.

HbUcqonlPDqtOQNqKvBg4Q.text: One of my favourite restaurants in London... I prefer having lunch here since they have an extended menu, plus it is less crowded and the service is much better than at dinner. Nowadays its really difficult to even get a reservation, but you can always pop in and try your luck at the bar, since it is not bookable and is reserved for walk ins. Best thing to do is come with lots of friends so you can order more small plates to share, that way you can try out everything since they change their menu regularly based on seasonal produce. The menu is very extensive and each item even has a "region" to tell you where the dish is from, but the standout dishes for me are the finger burning lamb(as good as it sounds), the truffle pasta(winter season), and the rum baba for dessert... actually pretty much any dessert there is bound to be amazing, it got so popular they even opened a gelato store across the road.For me a trip to London is not complete without eating at BDL!

xl2Yh92vyMCHW8wlJ3rekw.text: Marvellous food! Intimidatingly good wine list, professional friendly staff and it's right in the middle of town. I don't usually go wild for Italian food in the UK, but I have never had Italian food like this. Go to Bocca di Lupo. It is good. It's really very, very good.

1RyJrV4_-TBIqLhozJo2gQ.text: overrated. the fried rice balls (arancini) had glowing reviews but they were all bland. i couldn't tell the difference of each w/my eyes closed. the fish is really good here but everything else is not memorable and sadly less savory than described on the menu.very nice host/waiter though!

2A2OkfgD5tEyPdJaPF-yMg.text: Upscale London Italian.  Food and wine was great.  It was a bit on the pricey side however.  The wait staff was prompt and courteous.  The woman who sat us was a bit pretentious.  The tables are unnecessarily close to one another IMHO. This place gets packed, so be sure to make a reservation.

gOmIQB-B4_CDEz6uJ2sTVg.text: We came here on a recommendation from our Hotel's concierge and I'm glad we did! The food was absolutely delicious, one of the past dishes we got was to die for.  Almost the entire menu can me ordered in small and large portions. We opted to go for several small dishes, which was wonderful because we got to sample a bunch of different things. I can't wait to come back!

B7JJIMLyiyT535QIimy7Cg.text: Bocca di Lupo - Pics @ The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) Intrigued by all the hype surrounding Bocca di Lupo, I called up my dear Italian friend and foodie extraordinaire Tea (short for Teodora) for a meal at this very trendy establishment. Despite booking well in advance, we managed to get squeezed in for a 6pm sitting last Friday, and were reminded on arrival that our bit of counter should be vacated by 8pm, and no later. Bocca di Lupo is simply and informally decorated, tucked in on Archer Street, W1, one of the seediest streets in Soho. It was a runner-up in the Best New Italian Restaurants category of Time Out's 2010 Eating & Drinking Guide and had received rave reviews by fellow food bloggers World Foodie Guide and Londonelicious to name a few. The menu is not overly long or complicated, and clearly describes the Italian regions from which each of the dishes originate. I also enjoyed the possibility of ordering various dishes to share as opposed to having my own main course. We started the evening with Buffalo Mozzarella Bocconcini @ £2.50 each. As expected, these were very delicious and creamy. This was followed by Crescentini (fried bread) with Finocchiona, Speck & Squacquerone Cheese @ £5.50 (small). This was ok, although neither of us could taste the fennel in the fried bread, and felt that the accompanying portions of speck and cheese were rather meagre. The Shaved Radish, Celeriac and Pecorino Salad with Pomegranates and Truffle Oil £5.50 (small) was one of the highlights of the evening. The flavours and textures were diverse but came together nicely in the heavily scented truffle oil. I really enjoyed this dish and would certainly order it again. We ordered two of their pasta dishes, Tortellini with Cream and Nutmeg £8.00 (small), and Tagliatelle with Pigeon and Pork Ragu £7.00 (small). They were both good although to my surprise, the vegetarian option was the better of the two. The simplicity of the tortellini was refreshing, with the flavours of cream, cheese and nutmeg completely unadulterated and delicious. The Pigeon and Pork Ragu was also good and rich. The best dish of the evening was undoubtedly the Sea Bream Baked in Salt @ £16 (whole fish). The salty crust in which the fish was baked helped to season the flesh to perfection. It was reminiscent of Baccalá but without the chewiness and dense consistency of this salt-dried fish (cod). A true revelation. To accompany the fish we ordered a portion of Grilled Radicchio and Asiago Cheese @ £6.50 (small). The radicchio had been seasoned with balsamic vinegar and tasted sweet and slightly charred with the melted Asiago cheese (reminiscent of parmesan). We did not think it was an outstanding dish. For dessert, we ordered the Rum Baba with Pineapple and Whipped Cream £5.50 and the Brioche sandwich of Hazelnut, Pistachio and Chestnut Gelati (ice cream) £7.00. These were again fine, but rather unremarkable. I do not know if our mixed experience at Bocca di Lupo was because of my unduly high expectations or possibly because of the impersonal but efficient service we received. The food was good but not outstanding. I would like to give Bocca di Lupo another try when some of the hype finally quietens down. Verdict  Good Italian food at medium prices in Soho. Impersonal but efficient service. At £126.56 for four, Bocca di Lupo was relatively good value but hardly a bargain.

Q8eAhUHlQJc3Se1c1xragQ.text: One of the best italian restaurants in London. Very authentic and great tasting dishes. If you are looking for great italian food, I would definitely recommend this restaurant!

nN38OHOD5XvqDKAVkSJ6_A.text: I've been to London twice in the past month, and this was the one restaurant I HAD to return to. What's better yet is that I didn't repeat a single dish and everything I had on both visits was excellent. On first visit, we shared the fried mozzeralla, fried artichoke, a pre-theatre portion of meatballs braised in a lemon sauce, a side of chard and quite possibly the best spaghetti amatriciana ever. All the items were perfectly portioned, seasoned, executed - you name it. And the pre-theatre menu looks like a good deal if that's what you are up to (we just happened to be there early). The staff was great about steering us in right direction as far as how much food we needed to feel satiated and they were very helpful with the wine list.Our second visit was on the late end of the dinner hour, so we had only to contend with the normal dinner menu. As an app we shared the most incredible quartet of items: a fried piece of airy bread, two varieties of salumi and a cheese from the crescenza family. When all were paired together on the fork, it proved to be the perfect opening to another fine meal. After that tidbit, we moved onto the suckling pig, an orecchiette and a side of greens (yet again [a jet-lagged girl needs her fiber]). The pork was as decadent and heavy-handed (in a good way) as at a full on pig roast, with moist fatty interior and crispy crust. My only complaint was with the pasta, which was a little under seasoned. I let it slide because with a forkful of pig it balanced out. To finish things off, we split the duo of gelato - chocolate for me, and coconut for my husbie. Both amazing.I really, really love this spot and and chances are, when I live in London this summer, I'll be using it as an excuse to get me to a gym!

TJVOK7aGZRMk3owPBQKOhQ.text: I had tempered my expectations before dining at BDL, but I still felt sort of let down. Perhaps this was because so many respected food journalists had opined with such flattery about its merits and virtues. Or perhaps it is because we just didn't order right. I do hate the notion of not ordering the 'right' thing, though, as restaurants just shouldn't put 'wrong' dishes on the menu. But I don't think it was this either. I think it was just the feeling that, with a few minor adjustments, the food could have been so much better. So maybe it was just an off service in the kitchen, who knows. That said, what is clear is that BDL certainly serves up decent Italian food at reasonable prices (for central London) in a very appealing and comfortable dining space. And the menu is good fun too. The staff were all very pleasant, but we did find ourselves waiting around for long periods of time for someone to notice that we wanted or needed their attention. These often long gaps were all the more strange given that the restaurant wasn't even half full for most of the time we were there. Maybe they just lost focus as it was the end of the lunchtime service, but I can't imagine them being so lax in the middle of a completely packed out restaurant. Despite all of these niggles, I still did like BDL and would return, but certainly won't expect the world. For me, BDL is just a good, casual Italian restaurant serving reasonably priced food in a fun atmosphere  not the 'wolf' the press has made it out to be, devouring all other Italian establishments in the city of smoke.

nBm2BYOdubgGYPAWUggJrg.text: One word:  perfect.  I can go there every day.   Highly recommend their pasta dishes, if you like Italian way of making pastas (simple, fresh ingredients, al dente).  Just make a reservation and go... you won't regret (and yes, you will need a reservation)

NB-Ojd7lvvQCpiN1ba921A.text: A must  if you are interested in delicious, fresh, perfectly prepared Italian food. The entire experience at Bocca di Lupo is outstanding.  The food is scrumptious.  The decor is trendy.  The service is excellent.  Go for the food.  The menu is constantly changing.  The ingredients are fresh, beautifully presented and representative of the various regions of Italy.  Don't miss a stop across the street at Gelupo for dessert.  Owned and operated by Bocca di Lupo's proprietor/chef, the gelato is sensational!

4Nabcby7y4hPAGkXusjhdQ.text: This place was recommended by a couple of Italians I met recently in Tunisia. They considered it to be their favourite Italian in London & it was indeed very good. The bar area, in retrospect, would seem to be the best place for people & chef watching but we sat in the crowded & busy main part. Boy, was it busy for a Tuesday!!! Attracive & attentive staff & interesting regional food with only modest pasta offerings. Had a delicious cheesy & rockety risotto followed by some deep fried fish & seafood with polenta. Again, different & tasty. I thought the portions were a little small (always do though!) & the Moretti beer a little yeasty. Otherwise, well worth a visit.

TZxEKSdhuP0k95mvENd8ng.text: WENT BACK again last night. Bloody fantastic food and superb service from very busy wait staff. The Ricotta gnudi with lamb ragu was simply perfection. Cannot remember the wine, but the recommendation was faultless. Anywhere with a long busy bar where you can watch the chefs at work gets my votes. Actually, I would only want to sit at the bar here as I think the table area lacks atmosphere. I was impressed that they served a mean aperol spritzer - order one if you like an orangy sparkly pick me up for a drink. Stunning bread, but that is what you would expect from a son of the Sams at Moro. I think it is the same recipe and probably from the same sourdough starter. Very yum. Food stunning. For me, the dessert won it. Almond and blood orange granita with bitter chocolate ice cream. Hit every note perfectly. Bookings are hard to come by. Try for a late bar seat, say 9.30-10.00PM if you can wait that long.

rWJTrjXurh_u9gFDvnBnPw.text: Last Sunday was my third trip to Bocca Di Lupo in about 2 years.  Restaurant owners, take notice: just like an attractive woman can seem ugly because of her personality, a restaurant that serves great food can seem awful because of its servers.  Here is how it went:  We booked a table for 2 at the kitchen counter.  We arrived and were led to our seats. Immediately I noticed that the chairs were squeezed very tightly against each other with a rather large gentleman sitting to my right.  Seeing that there were two more open chairs to our right, we took them instead of the ones to the left. As I sat down on the wabbly chair, I realized that one chair had to be moved in order to be remotely comfortable so I moved it out of the way.  There was zero elbow room. The host got weirdly uncomfortable. Minutes later the manager came by and told me that he had two more people coming and that I had to put the chair back. My reply was: look, where is this chair supposed to go?  They were already stacked back to back with millimeters between them. He would not budge and shoved the other chair back in. Luckily the other diner was a sweet tiny old lady. Then they took my coat, gloves and umbrella to be stored. The umbrella never came back. I hope they're enjoying it today. The server was snooty and pushy. He did not explain anything on the menu and seemed grumpy and had an attitude like he just wanted to get us out of the way. I ordered the mushroom pasta and chorizo sausage that was overly rich and fatty. I've eaten here twice before and it was great, this time it was not. We asked for our check at the end and that took a good 15 minutes. So in a nutshell, this place was good, but its food quality declined and its services basically went into the toilet. There are many places to have good food in London, I recommend that you try them and leave this one to fix its issues.

3NVebSFmUKPbF02j4h6hlg.text: Bocca di lupo is wonderful.  Super intimate and very centrally located.  Oh and the food is amazing.  Very much a local's place.  If you want a nice evening out - cute place, delicious bites and great service, BDL is your spot!

QHggGEx75EP3VuS6YHUvhA.text: Went with my sister and her (now) fiance and it was a great visit from start to finish. We arrived a few minutes early, so they had yet to clear our table and set it up for us. As we waited, they offered us complementary prosecco and took our coats. Once we were seated, our waiter quickly appeared table-side to offer water and drinks. The cocktails we ordered were fabulous. I had a very summery cucumber and fruit drink which was really refreshing. From there, we asked some questions about how much to order (much of the menu is small plates, so you share), and then ordered about 7 dishes or so which was perfect. All of the food was well prepared and tasted great. The wine that our server helped pick out went brilliantly with the lamb. We also got dessert, which was fun because there's an option to get "mystery cones" so you have no idea what you're getting! Overall, great food. It's a bit on the pricey side, so this was the one 'fancy' dinner that we had while the visited. The great thing though, is that it's not overly fancy. You get the great service and food, but don't need to be dressed to the nines.Also, I'm told they try to keep bar seats for walk-ins (which is the best place to sit apparently) so you don't always need a reservation. (Though I'd recommend it)Visited March 2013

ryxQrwEV8W7cD2aivaSBqg.text: I should say first off that we ate the pre theatre menu. Got there about six being hungry in Soho and thinking it looked nice. Greeted by a very surly maitre'd who asked us if we had a booking (we did not) and said we could eat if we ate fast. We sat at the bar which is really cute because instead of barmen there are chefs, wouldn't recommend sitting there if there are more then two of you (neck ache would incur). Food was perfectly nice, I had pasta broccoli and my companion, pig cheeks and pasta. All and all a nice meal but we were in and out in 30 mins and did not appreciate the rude welcome. Would not my turn my cheek at going again but would book a table if I do so.

AiId0iNo2hnSLgvwlwzIQw.text: Please refer here for some photos and more:hungryinlondon.com/2011/…  it happens that, when you have finished writing a post, you press a wrong button and everything is lost. (why does the auto-save only work when you don't need it I wonder). This happened to me with my truly excellent Bocca Di Lupo post and I am writing it now again with significantly less enthusiasm I have to say. Despite my computer disability Bocca di Lupo deserves to be written up. I wanted to go there so many times already but never managed to get a table. This time however the queue in front of Spuntino was too long, so we moved on to Bocca Di Lupo located in a little Soho side street. After 20 odd minutes that we spent sipping prosecco and people watching we were finally seated at the bar. I like the atmosphere at Bocca Di Lupo very much. It is stylish and down to earth at the same time, the patrons being a good looking mixed crowd of post-theatre and pre-party diners. From the people at the reception to the waiting staff, everyone was very friendly, attentive and forthcoming. As the name already promises, Bocca di Lupo serves Italian food. I thought I would know or at least be able to translate most Italian dishes but when looking at the menu I realised that I had still a lot to learn. There were quite a few dishes I had never heard of and had not the faintest idea what they could possibly consist of. Provenance is a big issue as it is also stated in the menu from which Italian region the respective dish originates from, I do really like the fact that you can order small and large portions of most dishes which makes the food at Bocca di Lupo ideal for sharing (or not sharing for that matter). It is not exactly cheap and some of the dishes (see below) are bordering on seriously overpriced, but there are enough dishes under 10 pounds to choose from that you can get away with a non-bank breaking bill when ordering carefully. I had no idea what Crescentine, prosciutto sardo & squacquerone (7 small, 14 large) could possible be, so it had to be ordered. The 'bread' was reminiscent of fried pizza dough, still warm and very pleasant eaten together with the mild and creamy cheese (squacquerone stems from the Emilia Romagna) and the thinly sliced delicious prosciutto. This is comfort food of the highest standard. I have to order a dish that promises to be 'extremely spicy', in this case the Orecchiette with 'nduja (extremely spicy home-made salame) red onion & fresh tomato (7.00 small, 14 large). Finally a place in London were you get your pasta served al dente without having to fight for it and send the plate back 3 times! Again the thought of comfort food comes to mind. I have eaten more sophisticated pasta dishes, but this in its earthiness was rath enjoyable. Of note, it was spicy but not extremely so. For some vitamines we chose the Broad beans, rocket, lemon & mint (7.50). This I really thought was overpriced. Not a bad dish and certainly healthy but slightly tasteless and absolutely not worth 7.50 pounds! Or are broad beans an expensive ingredient?After so much green there had to be space for dolce . None of the usual suspects on the dessert menu  no tiramisu, no panna cotta and no zabaione. Again a lot of stuff I have never heard of and our choice finally fell on the Palle del nonno (6.50). 2 fried dough balls came filled with a hot chocolate/ricotta mix, faintly tasting of orange and this was unlike everything I have ever eaten before. It was quite nice but I don't think I would necessarily order it again. In addition, 6.50 pounds is just overpriced for this, particularly also considering the presentation (or better lack of any). In the end I did enjoy my visit at Bocca Di Lupo and I am intrigued to try more of their food. I was considering a green light and I would have given it, but the pricing seems a bit random particularly for dishes that can't cost very much to make.

U2WCgf5nkN4ZQBar1UIqsg.text: 3.5 stars.  Came here this weekend and managed to get seating for two at the around 6 PM on a Saturday.  The ambiance at least around the bar is nice - very active with people but still casual and friendly.  Our servers (we had two at different times) were also friendly.  The food, however, was very inconsistent: at times quite nice and at times quite disappointing.  Because more of the dishes were of the latter variety, I think this place is closer to 3 stars than 4.  First, a few things were excellent.  The olives that were served before the meal were absolutely spectacular.  These were among the best bites I have had in a long time and they were served as a complimentary starter.  Ask for seconds.  The focaccia that was served with olive oil prior to the meal was also excellent - very olive oil-y, in a good way.  In terms of main dishes, two items stood out: the homemade sausage with tomato and polenta (very good) and the orrechiette with spicy salami and basil (also excellent).  A veal saltimboca was also quite good - although two of us split opinion on this.  A second pasta dish was linguine with spider crab (just ok - the crab got a little lost in the dish and there wasn't a ton of flavor)Beyond that, other dishes ranged from mediocre to sub-par.  Two starters disappointed: (1) a salad with artichoke was bland and the artichoke was very tough; (2) courgette flowers with mozzarella and anchovy - this dish sounded absolutely fantastic but it had very little flavor and was quite oily - it could have used maybe a ricotta-type cheese n place of the mozzarella.  This place was good but not great.  A number of dishes missed the mark.  For upscale Italian food, the execution has to be better for a visit here to be worth it.

QjsX80mzZKcJL7NhuNrQiQ.text: Great experience, great service and really good food.  We had the much-mentioned radish salad with truffle oil, and it was perfectly balanced, unique and delicious.  My husband, who is more of a meat and potatoes guy, loved it.  The spicy orecchiette was very good, and definitely had a little bite. Everything we tried was tasty and well prepared.Out sweet Italian waitress was absolutely charming, and perfectly attentive even though they were quite busy. She took the time to explain the menu and her suggestions were spot-on.We will be back next time we are in London.

JgpGs2HCj5Y9ua_jdSw1VA.text: Kitchen closes at 11:00. If you are going to advertise that your place closes at midnight, then keep it open to atleast 11:30

FaG4minjuaYmJb_r_wuAqw.text: We wish we could give it 4.5. We found this restaurant with the help of Yelp. Just arrived in London from the US. I enjoyed the tortellini Parmesan. Family members enjoyed dory fish, a spicy pasta dish (forget the name) and sausage. Many delicious desserts - mini donuts with a side of chocolate was fantastic.

XYwv6mn2jNqLfjyrzXx6BQ.text: Top notch all around. Food was really amazing, ordered a few small plates and appetizers to share (risotto, tortellini...) as well as the lamb main. Friendly, authentically Italian chefs and waitstaff. Was seated at the counter, which was a little hot and noisy (as is typical) but close enough to the action to see the prep work which btw, is a great vantage point for deciding on which dishes you want :).

ninAH1t8OSsTUZ33chwYOw.text: Yes, I am a fan.  This place was hard to get in but I finally manage on my last day in London.  We were seated at the counter by the chef station.  How incredible to see the chefs all hard at work, it was like a life viewing on a cooking show.  Anyway on to the food.  I went with my friend who is a pescetarian but that didn't hold us back. Cream of red prawn risottoBlood orange, red onion & oreganoMonk fish cheeks with gremolataNettle & borage pansotti with walnut sauceRustic pork & foie gras sausage with farro & porcini (i had to)Everything was so good.  I especially liked the pansotti, the monk fish, and of course the sausage with farro.  Really really good.  I recommend anyone visiting london and looking for a no fail delicious meal.Service - excellent.Atmosphere - excellent.

rjNbpjsoL_VtxflQLj0A7g.text: Back for a second with some well-heeled guests and fellow frequent travellers. Another stand-out experience, this time putting ourselves in the hands of Rich and his team from truffle to menu to wine selection. Some unusual and exquisite choices which added to the conviviality of the evening. It's going to be a cold day in hell before I get tired of this experience.

n7KMyMAVbHSjDqSgLiMnDw.text: One of my favourite places to eat in London, let alone Soho. I've always sat at the bar, right in front of the kitchen at the chef's counter (I love seeing how my food is being made), and am amazed at how efficient this place is. The menu is constantly changing, but is always packed full of traditional Italian dishes. I still couldn't be tempted into trying any of the offal, but I know it's very good from the speed at which I've watched someone eat it! My favourite dishes here are the seasonal risottos, which change every so often, and are just to die for. Very, very good dessert as well, with exceptional espresso. Good service without being overbearing, and a truly comfortable environment that makes you want to stay all afternoon.

7mCsNCv1dN5PBAMsFnfNXQ.text: Great spot, cool scene, love the location, menu is inviting, but every dish was just a little bit off.That's the succinct version. I went here on a Friday night with my wife, and we were really excited to get seats at the counter. The location is very convenient to our usual late night haunt, and we love rustic Italian cuisine. Upon arrival, the staff was fun and attentive, which is a nice change in this city. We opened up a bottle of Primitivo that was decent and affordable, and ordered a bunch of small plates, with great help from our waiter.What followed were a variety of dishes that just didn't get the job done. The ideas were great, but everything was just not quite to the level it should have been, particularly with regard to salt. We found most dishes had a complete lack of it, while a couple had way too much. These basic flavoring issues happen, but when they're consistent across a meal that's going to cost sixty pounds without wine, I have a bit of a problem. That said, maybe it was a bad night.We'll likely go back and sit at the counter right in front of the kitchen for a better perspective. I really want to enjoy the place, and I like the choices on the menu. Hopefully I'll go back, and the execution will warrant the prices and popularity.

9kcRsyrFuMbYuV583ZIK5Q.text: BEST meal in london!  A coworker recommended this restaurant to me before I left and I was luckily able to snag reservations at the bar - which is the best place to sit because you can watch them make everything! (And Chef Adam is super cute!)This is the perfect Italian food - light, fresh, and tasty.  Must haves:Radish SaladGrilled OctopusFried MozzarellaSpicy OrecchietteTomatoes side (sounds boring, but probably the best tomatoes I've ever had)Dessert: Brioche sandwich of pistachio, hazelnut, & chestnut gelato (AMAZING - all three of my favorite flavors!)I ate so much that the chef was shocked by my big appetite.  It's in a cute neighborhood with really modern decor - a must go in London!

_JDIQSK-zoZGh85c9wapGw.text: Great italian place with a well-balanced menu that ticks all the variation of cuisines of the peninsula. It's got my favourite fried soft-shell crab in London. You absolutely have got to sit at the bar to marvel at how fast and slick the cooks are working to create the little magic of your plate. And the best is the service which is absolutely impeccable and makes you feel super special: we got in late for our reservation and felt quite bad as the kitchen was about to close soon, yet the waiter offered us some prosecco to get us cracking on our dinner and revigorate ourselves from a mad run through the streets of Soho to get there in time.

r6XlR9CLfhWLYGjRjNgROA.text: Fresh ingredients, piquant flavors and an attentive staff make this a restaurant worth visiting.  The extensive wine list had a number of hidden gems, including rarely seen producers and unappreciated varietals to which the knowledgable stand at the ready to direct you. Sit at the bar in front of the kitchen and watch the magic - it is a sight to behold.

sOKfBpiBV9tturJGej4zyw.text: What a sublime restaurant nestled in one of the most chaotic parts of London. If you are looking for delicious food, fantastic ambience and divine service Bocca di Lupo is your type of restaurant. I can only think of glowing things to say about this gem - from the abundant choice on the regional/seasonal menu to the service. It's simply perfect.I highly recommend sitting at the chef's counter so you can watch the preparation of meals - it's like a finely tuned symphony. Simply delightful. I've gone there three times, and I wouldn't hesitate in saying that it's my favourite restaurant in the city. A little pricey, but completely fair as going for a meal at Bocca di Lupo is a scrumptious and civilised meal experience.

GfkIpqIe-cXaQwPi0AotGg.text: This was just brilliant, popped in unknowingly and was blown away.The idea of small/big sharing for italian was very good. The calabrian N'duja pasta was dynamite.Price point is very good and you do get your moneys worth - big time.Service when we sat down was a bit slow (had to ask for wine-refill a number of times) but that's all forgotten as the greeting was fenomenal: a glass of wine/sparkling on the house while we wait. That's just A+ in my book.Food wise I'd recommend the N'duja and Spidercrab pasta as well as the small truffle dessert (cannot remember name) which actually is plenty to share for two if you just have that little sweet tooth after your meal.

K1xxEniKupD5buUPFbAVNg.text: Great place after the theatre, but there is also aprivate dinning room downstairs which serve as a great place for private dinners - the pig roast is a must!
